utterances: About 20 people form a prayer circle with Pastor Bruce Boria.
Just continue to pray Lord for the far-reaching implications of this act of kindness.
Many families who are struggling, perhaps this will bring a sense of hope for them.
Congregation member Katherine Minan knows all about the hope a person feels getting food.
She remembers as a child someone would anonymously drop off food boxes at her mom's mobile home.
I remember specifically opening the door one day and I probably was seven or eight, and I remember not saying anything.
I just saw the box and I turned around and my mother was there and we grabbed each other and we fell down on our knees and just hugged and cried.
We knew the potential of this box.
And over the next five years nearly half of all economic growth outside of the United States is projected to come from right here in Asia.
That makes this region an incredible opportunity for creating jobs and economic growth in the United States.
Today, the U.S.
and China announced an agreement to extend a travel visas in both directions so their valid for five or even 10 years, rather than just one.
The deal is designed to make it easier for tourists, students and business people from both countries to visit, study and invest abroad.
For years, Obama's a trade negotiators have been trying to forge a free trade agreement among a dozen Pacific countries.
Leaders of that group gathered today at the U.S.
Embassy in Beijing.
And while they didn't produce a final deal, Obama insists they are making good progress.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Agreements like this will benefit our economies and our people, but they also send a strong message that what's important isn't just whether our economies continue to grow, but how they grow.
For now, the trade pact known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership does not include China, the world's second-biggest economy.
But Obama insists the U.S.
is not trying to stifle China's growth.
Still, aides say Obama will confront Xi this week about more sensitive subjects including human rights and cyber espionage.
The White House says it's unacceptable that the Chinese government uses spy capabilities for the benefit of Chinese businesses.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
As they grow we want them to be a partner in underwriting the international order, not undermining it.
One question though is whether Obama himself has been undermined by his party's political fortunes back home.
I think when Southeast Asia looks at this trip and him coming, they're wondering who is Barack Obama now, after the midterm elections?
Ernest Bower is former president of the US-ASEAN Business Council.
President Obama has the Asia engagement DNA in his blood.
It's what he wants to do, but he's been sort of hijacked by domestic politics and the elections in the United States.
Bower says the jury is still out on whether Obama can regain his international prestige or if he's already a kind of lame, Beijing duck.
Ken Lieberthal says don't count Obama out just yet.
Lieberthal was former President Bill Clinton's point person on Asia during his last two years in office.
Like Obama, Clinton faced a hostile Congress but still managed to rack up some foreign-policy achievements.
I think it's important for the president to make clear by his posture, by his agenda - to show that he is determined to use his last two years in office to be a very active player in foreign-policy.
One plus for the president is the growing strength of the U.S.
economy.
While American voters are clearly dissatisfied with what they're seeing in their paychecks, many of the other countries represented at this week's summits are in much worse shape.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, Beijing.
Selma, Alabama yesterday saw a reenactment of what's known as Bloody Sunday.

Thousands of people including members of Congress and Vice President Joseph Biden marched across a bridge there, the same bridge civil rights protesters attempted to cross in 1965, as they marched from Selma to Montgomery, and were quickly met by police billy clubs and teargas.
Back then, Bloody Sunday galvanized support for the Voting Rights Act.
The commemoration is an annual event, but this year it comes just days after the U.S.
Supreme Court heard a challenge to a portion of that law.
Andrew Yeager from member station WBHM was at yesterday's march.
About a block away from the Edmund Pettus Bridge, where police and marchers clashed 48 years ago, Selma native Will Harris stands along the street.
He's excited.
It's the 25th time he's been here.
A camera hangs from his neck ready to capture the day's festivities.
It's just remarkable, man.
It's just a feeling you can't get over.
Especially when you're like in a building upstairs and you look out and can see thousands and thousands of people.
And you're like, this is in my city.
The annual reenactment may hearken back to the past, but its spirit is very much of the present.
Last week, justices heard a challenge brought by an Alabama county over part of the Voting Rights Act.
It's a provision which requires some states, mostly in the South, to get permission from the Justice Department before making changes to voting regulations.
Alabama officials argue that section is cumbersome and no longer necessary.
Questions asked by the court's conservative justices led some observers to suggest this part of the Voting Rights Act could be struck down.
In Selma, the Supreme Court is front of mind, as speaker after speaker alludes to the case.
The Reverend Jesse Jackson uses it to rally the crowd.
I must vote.
The Supreme Court can't take it.
If they try, we'll fight back.
Proponents of the law say voting rights still need to be protected.
Gwendolyn Ferreti, with the Hispanic Interest Coalition of Alabama, says some county registrars in the state are asking extra, unnecessary questions of naturalized citizens when registering.
Latino voters are viewed with suspicion.
This is something that we shouldn't be doing.
We shouldn't be limiting people's access to vote.
We should be trying to encourage as many people who are eligible to vote to do so.
(Singing) Going to let nobody turn me 'round, oh, turn me 'round, oh, turn me 'round.
Going to let nobody...
Marchers sing familiar anthems of the Civil Rights Movement, their voices bumping up against the roar of police motorcycles.
This time, police clear the way for the marchers as they stream onto the bridge.
Some are small children carried by parents.
Others return to the spot where they were bloodied 48 years ago.
The songs keep coming.
(Singing) This little light of mine, I'm going to let it shine, let it shine, let it shine...
The weight of this event isn't lost on Justin Dunn.
He's a student at Valparaiso University in Indiana, here on a school trip.
It will be the biggest story in American politics in a generation.
An African-American...
A thousand homes have been destroyed in San Diego County, and thousands more are still in danger as three large fires continue to burn out of control.
Authorities have evacuated 300,000 people from San Diego County.
The hot, dry Santa Ana winds that have been fanning the flames are not quite as strong today as they were yesterday, but forecasters say the shifting winds are a mixed blessing.
NPR's Scott Horsley joins us now on the line from San Diego.
And, Scott, Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger said yesterday that what San Diego needed was a break in the weather, and it's that what's happening now?
Well, Madeleine, in the eastern part of the county, the wind is still blowing out of the east.
It's a dry Santa Ana, but it's not as strong as it was yesterday.
That's allowing authorities to fight these fires with fixed-wing aircraft, which they couldn't do it this time yesterday.

Closer to the coast, the wind has begun blowing out of the west, off the ocean, and that's bringing in some moister air and keeping the fire from advancing to the west, but it's also in some cases pushing the fire back in new directions.
So San Diego's Emergency Services Chief Ron Lane said this is really a very unpredictable time.
We are in for another very dangerous day today.
The fact that the winds are starting to shift means that our population and our public really need to really pay attention to the news today.
Just because you're safe right now and the fire looks like it's going away from you, that could shift.
One indication of that - there are three big fires burning in San Diego County and one in the far northern end of the county.
It was quieter than expected overnight but at the same time a fire along the southern border with Mexico flared up.
That's caused new evacuation orders this morning, including an immigration detention center along the border.
Well, where are all these people going - 300,000 people?
A lot of folks are staying with friends and relatives in those parts of the county that are still safe, and there are still some parts of San Diego County that are not in the line of fire.
Some folks took shelter in hotels, although people in some cases who thought they were in a hotel that was safe were then forced to move on again in advance of the flames.
There are also about two dozen emergency shelters that have been set up around San Diego, the biggest at the Qualcomm Football Stadium.
And as of this morning, about 10,000 people were staying there.
That number is expected to grow as the south county fire flares up and causes new evacuations.
The mayor, Jerry Sanders, put out a call this morning for additional food, water, cots and pillows at Qualcomm.
So far, he says, the people in San Diego have really responded with an outpouring of assistance.

I think probably at Qualcomm Stadium we had as many volunteers as we had as people affected, and I think that that was people working together, feeling good about helping each other and feeling good about accepting that help.
We are told that the scene in Qualcomm Stadium was very orderly overnight.
And just in case, there were some National Guard troops on hand.
Mayor Sanders says they made the people there feel very cared for in maybe the special way that only a uniformed National Guardsman can do.
So Scott, any idea from firefighters when they hope to get these fires under control?
A huge amount of firefighting resources are coming into the county - hundreds of additional ground troops, additional aircraft to fight the fire from the sky.
So in a sense the cavalry is arriving, but these are massive fires and it's going to take time.
Every time the firefighters get a break in one part of the county, the fire moves out of control in another part of the county.

They are talking about letting some people go back to their homes or what's left of their homes in places that have already burned or where the fire has passed on, but they're doing that in a very deliberate timetable.
What they don't want to do is have people go back into an area only to have to evacuate them again.
NPR's Scott Horsley covering the fires from San Diego.
Thank you.
My pleasure, Madeleine.
And here's more from that San Diego stadium, Qualcomm, that's now a refugee center for thousands.
Reporter Andrew Phelps of member station KPBS San Diego spoke with a family that fled its home in the town of Poway.
This is how Ryan Anderson and his twin daughters evacuated.
I was asleep and my girls were in bed and we had a pound on the door.
It was the Poway Search Department, said that we had to leave, and we opened our door.
The smoke and the ash were so bad we couldn't even breathe.
I mean, we looked like we were actually a different color when we came out of our apartment.
